node.author: Steven Levy
node.title: Insanely Great
node.notes: This book details the creation of the Macintosh.

node.author: Brian Dear
node.title: The Friendly Orange Glow
node.notes:
A great story about a different "internet", before The Internet. The PLATO project started as an automatic teaching platform but, by crafting and encouraging a community of young and curious developers to stretch the limits of the system. This was done in the 60s and 70s and using a mainframe! Definitely well worth a look at this book if you're interested in the history of computing and the internet.
It's also very interesting how Douglas Engelbart and Alan Kay's names tend to be brought up when we talk about the beginning of personal computing.

node.author: Ken Blanchard
node.title: Leading at a Higher Level: Blanchard on Leadership and Creating High Performing Organizations
node.notes:
I didn't actually finish reading this book, I actually abandoned it. There were some interesting ideas about  understanding and communicating with the team member in which phase of development they're in, but at every other page there was a reference to another Blanchard book and I grew tired of it.
Also for every paragraph of concept there seemed to be pages and pages of examples that really didn't add much.

node.author: William Gibson
node.title: Ghost Territory
node.notes: Not as good as Pattern Recognition, but this second book on the Blue Ant trilogy is also a page turner.

node.author: John Doerr
node.title: Measure What Matters
node.notes: Good explanation of OKRs (of course), but there are a lot of extra chapters with anedoctal stories about implementing OKRs in different companies that felt a lot like fillers.

node.author: William Gibson
node.title: Pattern Recognition
node.notes: [wip]. This is the 7th book by William Gibson that I read. I can't help but be amazed by his stories. Pattern Recognition tells the story of a "cool-hunter", that is hired to solve a mistery. But the story, set in the real world, is full of incredible cultural references. From a weird mechanical calculator to a cool jacket, passing by a japanese movie director and french philosophers.

node.author: Neil Postman
node.title: The Disappearance of Childhood
node.notes:
Picked this book after going on an Alan Kay binge and coming across this [list of book recommendations](http://www.squeakland.org/resources/books/readingList.jsp). The list was mentioned by Alan Kay himself in a [quora answer](https://www.quora.com/What-are-Alan-Kays-favorite-books?q=alan%20kay%20book.%20).
The book itself proposes an interesting idea that childhood appeared when there was a separating factor between the adult world and the child's world. To prove this point he mentions the dark ages, when children (7+ years) were sent off to apprentice. When Gutemberg invented the printing press this changed. The world was divided between those who could read and those who could not. And when that happened, we could keep 'secrets' and the ugly face of society from kids.
After setting this picture up he moves to how television and its visual, instead of intelectual, form of consumption is erasing this distinction.

node.author: David Allen
node.title: Getting Things Done
node.notes: Reading it for the second time, almost 10 years later, this felt like a breath of fresh air. The book is much more insightful than I remembered it to be. Written before smartphones were a thing the knowledge contained in it is timeless, but the book is dated because  of all the mentions of tools and briefcases.

node.author: Donella Meadows
node.title: Thinking in Systems: A Primer
node.notes: Very good and concise intro to systems thinking. Starts of with pretty basic concepts, such as stocks and inflows and outflows, but quickly adds complexity and nuance to what is being explained.

node.author: Bruce Patton, Douglas Stone e Sheila Heen
node.title: Conversas difíceis — Como discutir o que é mais importante
node.notes: This books seems to have found me in the right moment. I initially read the intro only and was immediately hooked in. The whole framework about the conversations about what happened, about impact and about emotions is a very powerful framework to keep in mind. Sheila Heen, one of the authors, is also one of the authors of another book I have reviewed very well, "Thanks for the feedback".

node.author: Will Larson
node.title: An Elegant Puzzle: Systems of Engineering Management
node.notes: I think the book aims at a different level of Engineering Management than I have been exposed to. The book  has a lot of good references, though, which is very helpful for deeper dives in other subjects
